question: When reporting on energy management, what is a key difference in the disclosure requirements between the Aerospace & Defense industry and the Meat, Poultry & Dairy industry?
optionA: Only Aerospace & Defense must report the percentage of grid electricity used
optionB: Only Meat, Poultry & Dairy must report the percentage of renewable energy used
optionC: Aerospace & Defense must report energy consumption in kilowatt-hours, while Meat, Poultry & Dairy reports in gigajoules
optionD: Meat, Poultry & Dairy must include energy from biomass sources, while Aerospace & Defense does not
optionE: Aerospace & Defense must report energy intensity, while Meat, Poultry & Dairy does not have this requirement
answer: D: Meat, Poultry & Dairy must include energy from biomass sources, while Aerospace & Defense does not
explanation: While both industries must report total energy consumed, percentage of grid electricity, and percentage of renewable energy, the Meat, Poultry & Dairy industry has specific requirements for including energy from biomass sources in its renewable energy calculations. This requirement is not present in the Aerospace & Defense industry standards.

question: In terms of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions reporting, what is a key difference between the disclosure requirements for the Hardware industry and the Meat, Poultry & Dairy industry?
optionA: Only Hardware must report Scope 1 emissions
optionB: Only Meat, Poultry & Dairy must report Scope 1 emissions
optionC: Hardware must report product lifecycle emissions, while Meat, Poultry & Dairy does not
optionD: Meat, Poultry & Dairy must discuss strategies to manage Scope 1 emissions, while Hardware does not have this requirement
optionE: Hardware must report emissions from manufacturing facilities, while Meat, Poultry & Dairy reports emissions from livestock
answer: D: Meat, Poultry & Dairy must discuss strategies to manage Scope 1 emissions, while Hardware does not have this requirement
explanation: The Meat, Poultry & Dairy industry has a specific requirement (FB-MP-110a.2) to discuss long-term and short-term strategies to manage Scope 1 emissions, including reduction targets and performance analysis. The Hardware industry does not have a similar requirement focused on Scope 1 emissions management strategies in its disclosure standards.

question: When calculating the percentage of products meeting environmental standards, what is a key difference between the metrics used in the Hardware industry and the Household & Personal Products industry?
optionA: Hardware uses EPEAT, while Household & Personal Products uses Energy Star
optionB: Household & Personal Products focuses on palm oil certification, while Hardware does not have a similar product-specific metric
optionC: Hardware calculates based on revenue, while Household & Personal Products uses unit sales
optionD: Household & Personal Products includes packaging in its calculations, while Hardware does not
optionE: Hardware considers product energy efficiency, while Household & Personal Products only considers chemical content
answer: B: Household & Personal Products focuses on palm oil certification, while Hardware does not have a similar product-specific metric
explanation: The Household & Personal Products industry has a specific metric (CG-HP-430a.1) for the percentage of palm oil sourced that is certified to RSPO standards. The Hardware industry does not have a similar product-specific environmental certification metric, instead focusing on broader standards like EPEAT and ENERGY STAR for its products.

question: When reporting on water management, what is a key difference in the metrics between the Health Care Delivery industry and the Meat, Poultry & Dairy industry?
optionA: Only Health Care Delivery reports on water quality compliance
optionB: Only Meat, Poultry & Dairy reports on water consumed in high stress regions
optionC: Health Care Delivery reports on wastewater treatment, while Meat, Poultry & Dairy does not
optionD: Meat, Poultry & Dairy must report on water risks in its supply chain, while Health Care Delivery does not
optionE: Health Care Delivery reports water use per patient, while Meat, Poultry & Dairy reports per animal
answer: D: Meat, Poultry & Dairy must report on water risks in its supply chain, while Health Care Delivery does not
explanation: The Meat, Poultry & Dairy industry has specific metrics (FB-MP-440a.1 and FB-MP-440a.2) related to water risks in its supply chain, including the percentage of animal feed sourced from water-stressed regions and the percentage of contracts with producers in water-stressed regions. The Health Care Delivery industry does not have similar supply chain water risk metrics in its disclosure requirements.

question: How do the climate change-related disclosure requirements differ between the Aerospace & Defense industry and the Meat, Poultry & Dairy industry?
optionA: Only Aerospace & Defense must report on climate change impacts
optionB: Only Meat, Poultry & Dairy must discuss climate change strategies
optionC: Aerospace & Defense focuses on product emissions, while Meat, Poultry & Dairy focuses on operational emissions
optionD: Meat, Poultry & Dairy must address climate impacts on feed and livestock, while Aerospace & Defense focuses on fuel efficiency
optionE: Aerospace & Defense reports on climate adaptation, while Meat, Poultry & Dairy reports on climate mitigation
answer: D: Meat, Poultry & Dairy must address climate impacts on feed and livestock, while Aerospace & Defense focuses on fuel efficiency
explanation: The Meat, Poultry & Dairy industry has a specific requirement (FB-MP-440a.3) to discuss strategies for managing climate change risks and opportunities related to feed sourcing and livestock supply. In contrast, the Aerospace & Defense industry focuses on fuel economy and emissions of products (RT-AE-410a.2), emphasizing strategies to address fuel efficiency and GHG emissions in their products.

question: How do the waste management disclosure requirements differ between the Health Care Delivery industry and the Hardware industry?
optionA: Only Health Care Delivery must report on hazardous waste
optionB: Only Hardware must report on e-waste recycling
optionC: Health Care Delivery reports on medical waste, while Hardware reports on end-of-life product recovery
optionD: Hardware must report on packaging waste, while Health Care Delivery does not
optionE: Health Care Delivery reports waste per patient, while Hardware reports waste per product unit
answer: C: Health Care Delivery reports on medical waste, while Hardware reports on end-of-life product recovery
explanation: The Health Care Delivery industry has specific metrics (HC-DY-150a.1 and HC-DY-150a.2) for reporting on medical waste, including its disposal methods and pharmaceutical waste management. In contrast, the Hardware industry focuses on end-of-life product recovery and recycling (TC-HW-410a.4), reporting on the weight of end-of-life products and e-waste recovered, and the percentage recycled.
